description: These FDA approved drugs for infected patients may be effective in patients who would otherwise not have any other treatment options other than supportive care. Chloroquine in particular should be inexpensive and is given orally.
summary: There are currently no FDA approved drugs for the treatment of Ebola, but there are drugs that are FDA approved for other indications that have activity against the virus. Chloroquine is an inexpensive drug that was used for malaria treatment until drug resistance developed. The drug has good activity against the virus in animals and could potentially be used to treat patients and as prophylaxis in healthcare workers who are at high risk. The selective estrogen receptor modulator clomiphene is another FDA approved drug that works in animal models. Finally interferon beta has been used to treat multiple sclerosis, and also has activity against Ebola in animal models.
title: Treating  infected patients with FDA approved drugs that have activity against the virus
